references: The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The novel PFL scheme is introduced in SectionÂ II. A generic client clustering algorithm is proposed and solved in SectionÂ III. Extensive simulations are performed to validate the proposed method in SectionÂ IV. Finally, the conclusions are drawn in SectionÂ V. A summary of symbols and notations is provided in TableÂ I.

S4.T2.caption: TABLE II: Number of required rounds to reach 97%percent9797\% accuracy for the CNN model on the MNIST dataset. Columns represent the number of clusters and rows represent number of sub-channels
S4.T2.table:
K\N 1 2 4 8
1 273 (0%) 180 (0%) 152 (0%) 118 (0%)
2 186 (32%) 129 (28%) 109 (28%) 106 (10%)
3 139 (49%) 129 (28%) 114 (25%) 100 (15%)
4 131 (52%) 122 (32%) 105 (30%) 97 (18%)
references:
First, we have validated the proposed method using the MNIST dataset [21], which consists of hand-written digits. In the simulation scenario, we assumed that there are M=1500ğ‘€1500M=1500 clients. We assumed that the number of data samples (i.e., images of hand-written digits) per client nmsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šn_{m} is uniformly distributed between nmin=10subscriptğ‘›10n_{\min}=10 samples and nmax=70subscriptğ‘›70n_{\max}=70 samples. We compared the results of PFL to the conventional federated learning scheme where there is only one cluster. We considered four possible scenarios for the ratio between the variation in computation time to communication time in (22). We performed the simulations for 111, 222, 333, and 444 clusters, respectively. We also studied the effect of the number of sub-channels on the performance of PFL. Hence, we varied the number of sub-channels as 111, 222, 444, and 888, respectively. Each sub-channel can be used by a single client only at a given time instant.
We used two different deep learning models for the training of the MNIST dataset. The first model is a two-layer CNN model with 323232 and 646464 5Ã—5555\times 5 filters, respectively.
The second model is an MLP model with two layers with 200200200 nodes in each layer.
We run the training algorithm for up to 100010001000 rounds of global model (server) updates. We obtained the model prediction accuracy by testing the trained model on a separate test dataset as a function of the number of communication rounds.
The batch size is chosen as 161616, and the number of local epochs is set to 111. The client learning rate is optimized using a multiplicative parameter grid, and the server learning rate (the scaling factor) is set to 111.
The number of required rounds to reach 97%percent9797\% accuracy for the CNN model trained on the MNIST dataset is shown in TableÂ II. Similarly, the number of required rounds to reach 96%percent9696\% accuracy for the MLP model trained on the MNIST dataset is shown in TableÂ III.

As seen in TableÂ II and TableÂ III, applying clustered scheduling enables achieving faster convergence (in terms of the number of iterations) in comparison with a baseline federated learning approach with no clustering.
The conventional federated learning scheme with the CNN model achieves 97%percent9797\% accuracy in 273273273, 180180180, 152152152, and 118118118 rounds with 111, 222, 444, and 888 sub-channels, respectively. The proposed PFL scheme provides 32%percent3232\% gain compared to the conventional federated learning scheme in terms of required rounds by employing only 222 clusters. The gain provided by clustering is improved for each additional cluster in the system. The marginal gain provided by the PFL scheme decreases with the increasing number of sub-channels since the effective number of data samples per communication round is already enough for the conventional federated learning.

S4.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Number of required rounds to reach 97%percent9797\% accuracy for the CNN model on EMNIST dataset. Columns represent the number of clusters and rows represent number of sub-channels
S4.T4.table:
K\N 1 2 4 8
1 686 (0%) 221 (0%) 189 (0%) 170 (0%)
2 274 (60%) 184 (17%) 178 (6%) 160 (6%)
3 191 (72%) 182 (18%) 158 (16%) 158 (7%)
4 191 (72%) 175 (21%) 156 (17%) 160 (6%)
references:
In this section, we use the extended version of the MNIST dataset, namely, EMNIST [22]. We use the federated EMNIST dataset in which the data is already distributed to the clients by their writing styles. The EMNIST dataset has letters additionally; however, we will use only the digits dataset. The federated EMNIST digits dataset has a total of 341,873341873341,873 train and 40,8324083240,832 test samples distributed among 3,38333833,383 clients. There are 101010 classes in the dataset, each corresponding to a hand-written digit. The data distribution among the clients is shown in Fig.Â 4. As seen from Fig.Â 4, the distribution of the number of data samples among the clients is unbalanced and not uniform.
We formulate the client clustering problem as shown in (23) for clustering the clients for the federated EMNIST dataset, and then we solve the problem efficiently using AlgorithmÂ 2. Accordingly, in the training step, we first cluster the clients using the proposed optimization problem. Then, we train the model using the PFL scheme. We performed the simulations for 111, 222, 333, and 444 clusters and 111, 222, 444, and 888 sub-channels, respectively. We used a two-layer CNN model with 323232 and 646464 5Ã—5555\times 5 filters as the neural network model. The batch size is chosen as 161616, and the learning rate is optimized using a multiplicative parameter grid. The number of local epochs is chosen as 111 in order to assess the convergence speed. The required number of rounds to achieve 97%percent9797\% accuracy for the EMNIST digits dataset is given in TableÂ IV.

The number of communication rounds required is 686686686 for the 111 sub-channel and 111 cluster case. The number of communication rounds drops by 64%percent6464\% to 274274274 rounds by introducing 111 additional cluster. The number of communication rounds gets lower and lower with the increasing number of clusters. The gain from the proposed PFL scheme decreases if the number of available sub-channels increases. Therefore, we could conclude that the proposed scheme may not be feasible if the number of sub-channels is sufficiently large, e.g., more than 444 sub-channels in this case.
As seen from TableÂ IV, the model converges faster for a higher number of clusters in the system. However, the marginal gain obtained by each additional cluster decreases with the number of clusters already present in the system.

S4.T5.caption: TABLE V: Number of required rounds to reach 40%percent4040\% accuracy for the two-layer LSTM model on Shakespeare dataset. Columns represent the number of clusters and rows represent number of sub-channels
S4.T5.table:
K\N 1 2 4 8
1 1182 (0%) 661 (0%) 429 (0%) 354 (0%)
2 605 (49%) 379 (43%) 273 (36%) 213 (40%)
3 419 (65%) 282 (57%) 239 (44%) 198 (44%)
4 372 (69%) 257 (61%) 215 (50%) 190 (46%)
references:
For modeling time-series data, we used federated Shakespeare dataset [1, 23] for training a stacked two-layer  long short-term memory (LSTM) network. Federated Shakespeare dataset is built by combining all works of Shakespeare.
The dataset consists of the speaking roles of 715715715 characters in each play, corresponding to the clients in our federated learning setup. The dataset is unbalanced since most of the plays have a few lines, and a small number of clients have a high count of lines in their plays. Additionally, the number of data samples is not distributed uniformly to the clients. It is also clear that the dataset is not  independent identically distributed (i.i.d.) since the dataset is distributed to the clients according to the played character.
We use AlgorithmÂ 2 for determining the clusters for the clients. Then, we train the model using the proposed PFL scheme.
The neural network model used for this task has an embedding layer at the input, which embeds the input characters into an 888 dimensional space. After the embedding layer, it has two LSTM layers with 256256256 hidden nodes. Finally, it has an output layer with softmax activation with an output for each character.
In training, we set the batch size to be 101010 and optimized the learning rate through a multiplicative parameter grid.
The simulation results for the application of PFL for the training of the two-layer LSTM network on the Shakespeare dataset are given in TableÂ V. The rows represent the number of clusters, and the columns represent the number of sub-channels. The values are given in terms of the number of rounds required to reach 40%percent4040\% accuracy in the training.
By examining the simulation results for both federated the EMNIST and the Shakespeare datasets, we conclude that the proposed pipelining scheme improves the results for non-uniformly distributed data more significantly.
